title: 112_hr2707
content: The Act is titled the "Agricultural Trade Facilitation Act" and includes Congressional findings. Congress finds that it has the authority to establish negotiating objectives for agricultural trade agreements. The value of US agricultural exports has more than doubled in the past decade, supporting a significant number of jobs. In 2009, agricultural exports supported 830,000 American jobs. There are concerns about non-science-based barriers restricting trade, affecting agricultural exports and jobs. Sanitary and phytosanitary measures aim to protect human, animal, and plant health from various risks in food and agriculture. Sanitary and phytosanitary measures involve specific standards, quarantine regulations, certification procedures, and testing requirements. Currently, there are 37 active disputes within the WTO regarding these measures. The WTO Agreement on Sanitary and Phytosanitary Measures recognizes the rights of each country in implementing these measures. The WTO Agreement on Sanitary and Phytosanitary Measures recognizes each country's rights to implement science-based measures to protect health without unjust discrimination. Improper use of measures can create barriers to trade, as seen in a review of notifications from 50 countries in 2010. The United States Government commented on 173 proposed or in-force sanitary and phytosanitary measures, with comments on processed products, live animals, fish, new standards for plants, bulk commodities, and horticultural products. Non science-based barriers continue to threaten US agricultural exports. A Department of Agriculture study found questionable technical barriers in over 60 countries affecting trade in 300 agricultural products, valued at $5 billion of US exports. The United States Trade Representative asserts that sanitary and phytosanitary trade barriers hinder US producers from shipping millions of dollars worth of goods, impacting farms and small businesses. The Agreement on Sanitary and Phytosanitary Measures aims to reduce improper trade barriers through harmonization, transparency, and dispute settlement. Strengthening these rules is crucial for future trade agreements to benefit US exporters. Trade negotiating objectives of the United States regarding the application of sanitary and phytosanitary measures to agricultural products. The United States aims to secure more open, equitable, and reciprocal market access by strengthening rules on sanitary and phytosanitary measures for agricultural products in trade agreements. This includes requiring scientific evidence and risk assessments for regulations. The agreement aims to encourage active participation in developing international standards for regulations, promoting regulatory coherence, and evaluating health and safety protection systems for imported products. The agreement aims to ensure that the exporting party's system meets or exceeds the importing party's end-product standards. It also requires transparency in developing and implementing measures, including publishing proposed measures with scientific justification for public comment, and conducting risk analysis in a timely manner. The agreement aims to improve risk assessments based on relevant scientific data, require validated test methods for imported products, promote harmonization of export certification requirements, and limit information on export documents to meet sanitary and phytosanitary standards. The agreement aims to improve risk assessments, require validated test methods for imported products, promote harmonization of export certification requirements, and limit information on export documents to meet sanitary and phytosanitary standards, ensuring enforceable trade obligations through an efficient dispute settlement process. SEC. 4. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act takes effect on the date of enactment and applies to negotiations for trade agreements related to sanitary and phytosanitary measures for agricultural products. Exceptions include specific trade agreements and the Doha Development Round of the World Trade Organization.
